column4: This introductory-level class focuses on how music is organized by time. We will discuss rhythm and related concepts such as meter and tempo. The basics of modern Western rhythmic notation will be introduced, and class members will practice reading and producing simple rhythms. No instruments required--just bring yourself!

column3: Intro to Pitch and Modern Staff Notation
column4: In this class, you will learn how to identify notes on a staff and relate them to audible pitches. We will also talk about accidentals, treble and bass clefs, and scales.

There are a few rough patches for the recorder novice, even one who reads music or plays another instrument already. This workshop teaches the fundamentals of breathing, finger placement, tonguing, dynamics and phrasing. We'll also talk about the history of the instrument. Given time, we can also cover topics such as reading music (if most of the students don't already know how) or simple historical techniques. Recorders and lesson book will be available.
Putting together the stuff from the first part of the day. Reading really simple straight forward music. Bring whatever instrument you want. Or you can sing too.
Taking a piece of challenging music, or music that is played at a rapid speed, and making it so you can play along no matter what level you're at.

In this class we'll go over how to make your performance of dance melodies more interesting to listen to, less boring to play, and more period by adding period appropriate ornaments. This is a hands on class. Bring your instrument of choice.

Music is a social activity, and as much as a performer communicates with his or her audience, more do performers communicate with one another when playing in ensemble. This lecture / workshop emphasizes the fundamentals of ensemble playing: leading, following, listening, responding. Oh, and tuning. Whether you're singing, playing a melody instrument, a harmonizing instrument such as a vihuela de mano, percussion, or any other instrument, we will address your musical role. If there's time, we'll talk about renaissance examples of musical ensembles.

column3: Intonation - How to Play in Tune
column4: In this class we'll practice singing and playing in Just Intonation. Bring your voice or your non-fixed-pitch instruments (like recorders and violins) and we'll make some consonant noise together.

This class can be summarized as "Lyrics win! And if there are no lyrics...". How do you make a piece of music sound like something other than just one note after another? What patterns are there that you should recognize and know? Why should percussionists study poetry? What to look for in a piece of music that gives you a clue how to shape it, and what tools do you need to do that shaping? An ability to read modern notation will be helpful, but not strictly required. Bring (soft) instruments or warmed up voices to class, we'll be making noises.

If you play music, you probably know what a scale is, but medieval music didn't! Come learn what they did use instead. "We'll start at the beginning" and learn where Do-Re-Mi started. Handout includes music in each mode, and class will teach you how to tell which it is. Bring a pencil.

column3: Neumes to Notes - performing Cantigas d'Amigo by Martin Codax
column4:
This class will present a case study, preparing a performance of the Cantigas d'Amico by Martin Codax. We will look at the extant manuscript (c.1275) and explore the problems of transcription from neumes to notes. We will review available modern editions and recordings, and the different choices made by different editors. We will examine the process by which a group makes decisions about instrumentation and arrangements.

Prerequisite: Since many of the issues revolve around notation, an ability to read (modern) notation will be very helpful, although not strictly required.
Lets just have fun playing. Bring any instrument and your Red, Green and Blue books (The Recorder Consort by Steve Rosenberg) and I will pick some easier pieces that are accessible to everyone.

In this class we'll find either a song people already know (King Henry's Madrigal?) or one that's very easy to learn (Sumer is icumen in?) and work on how to get your nose out of your sheet music and pay attention to your audience... which, in turn, makes them want to pay attention to you!

column3: Guillaume de Machaut: Rockstar of the 14th Century
column4: Composer, poet and courtier Guillaume de Machaut's fame, long career and prolific writing in his day rivals the Rolling Stones in ours. This class is a sight-reading jam session with some commentary about the composer and aspects of his works. Players will explore several of Machaut's works that are musically interesting even if you don't know French. The teachers are instrumentalists, but if singers attend who do read French, they are welcome to sing those tunes with lyrics. Audience welcome as space permits.

column3: How to Switch Recorders (or Play from Other Clefs)
column4:
In this class we'll discuss how to go from a C recorder to an F recorder, and then spend most of our time practicing doing just that. Some fairly straight-forward music will be handed out that's suitable to different sizes of recorder. For more advanced players we'll have some editions of the music in various C clefs, Baritone Clef, French Violin Clef, and facsimile.

Note: This class will be geared toward recorder players, although other musicians are welcome to join in. The ideal student is one who can sight-read proficiently either soprano or alto recorder.

Is the swan in in "Il Bianco" really dying over and over again or is he "dying le petit mort" as it were? ... ^_~ Or is "Of all the Birds" really about a sparrow? Which double meanings of today were intended then? And which were intended then that are not used today? All these questions and more will be answered in this class.

column3: Le Roman de Fauvel: A Horse Is a Horse . . . Or Is He?
column4: Le Roman de Fauvel is a satirical poem from the early 14th century that was turned into an elaborate illuminated manuscript with narrative text, paintings and accompanying music both monophonic and polyphonic. It tells the story of an evil horse named Fauvel, his tenure over man in a reversal of man's dominion over beasts and his search for love and security. This class will explore the story and manuscript as well as listen to a selection of recorded music from Le Roman de Fauvel.

column3: Claudio Monteverdi - Life, Work, and Legacy
column4: It is often recognized but not so often emphasized how instrumental Claudio Monteverdi had been in shaping the history of music as we know it today. This workshop attempts to place the life and works of Monteverdi in their historical context, discussing the early influences he had acting on him as well as the influence he had on future generations of composers. A historical discussion, with plenty of musical excerpts to listen to.

Musica ficta are notes which are not normally present in the mode of a piece of early renaissance music (i.e. accidentals), but which were meant to be added by performers according to a set of rules. They are often notated in modern editions of period music as accidental signs above the note. In this class, we will go over the rules and how to apply them to period manuscripts. Exciting topics such as avoiding tritones and the tierce de Picardie will be discussed.

column3: What to Listen for At the Concert
column4: Listening to a piece of music can be more than just a passive activity. When we know the historical context, theoretical ideals, and important musical aspects of a piece, we are better able to listen and appreciate what we hear. In this class, we will examine the music of tonight's concert and the features that make these pieces special. The class is aimed at both musicians and non-musicians.

column3: Master Class led by Mistress Amelie
column4:
Mistress Amelie Leads Second Annual St. Cecilia Master Class -- This is a class for performers to play a piece of 3 to 5 minutes in length that they have prepared ahead of time. They will then receive advice, suggestions and coaching from the instructor on their performance, and things they might do to improve it. The class is limited to 3 performing participants (or ensembles), with an unlimited number of auditors. Performers should expect to send a copy of the performing edition of their sheet music to the instructor a week ahead of time.

Performers are:
Court and Country
Kasha Alekseeva

column3: Midrealm Division 1 A&S Criteria Revision Discussion
column4: During Lunch Lady Kasha, Lady Arin, and Lady Jadzia will lead a discussion on how to improve the Midrealm Division 1 A&S criteria. More info on this to come shortly.

column3: Master Class led by Master Robyyan
column4: Master Robyyan Leads First Annual St. Cecilia Master Class -- This is a class for perfomers (preferably ensembles) to play a piece of 3 to 5 minutes in length that they have prepared ahead of time. They will then receive advice, suggestions and coaching from the instructor on their performance, and things they might do to improve it. See the Wikipedia article on master classes for an excellent description. The class is limited to 3 performing participants (or ensembles), with an unlimited number of auditors. Performers should expect to send a copy of the performing edition of their sheet music to the instructor a week ahead of time. Performers are:Court and CountryPsallite

if you already play recorder at a decent level you are half-way to playing crumhorn. Bring your's (or borrow from a limited number of 'loaners') and learn how to play a 'buzzy' without making people laugh. Emphasis on hands-on playing. Good practice for the Small Ensemble at KWDMS.
Technique for Intermediate Recorder Players
A practical class for instrumentalists to develop skill in ensemble ornamentation / improvisation around a chordal framework.
Walking through the process of reading lute tab. Bring your Lute (or Guitar [and capo if you have one; not strictly necessary]). Prerequisite: Know how to tune your guitar...
Want to read new recorder music faster? Want to be able to play a new dance on the spot? Come to this class! Will be good preparation for evening sight-reading.

This introductory-level program is a sampler of early vocal music between the 9th-10th century and the turn of the 17th century. The focus for this program is primarily nonliturgical music designed for solo performance.

In this class we'll find either a song people already know (King Henry's Madrigal?) or one that's very easy to learn (Sumer is icumen in?) and work on how to get your nose out of your sheet music and pay attention to your audience... which, in turn, makes them want to pay attention to you!
In this class we'll start with conducting patterns patterns, learn how to bring people in and cut them off and discuss song selection, among other things. Participatory class
This class will discuss Early Opera that just makes the cut-off for SCA Period.

column3: Pérotin and the Music of the Notre Dame School
column4: This class will discuss features of the compositional style of the Notre Dame school, a group of composers working at the Notre Dame Cathedral between 1150 and 1260. It will explain organum, rhythmic modes and modal notation, and the development of the motet. The piece "Alleluia, Nativitas" by Pérotin will be examined as one example of the Notre Dame compositional style.

column3: Practical Challenges in Running an Early Music Ensemble
column4: Think running an Early Music group is easy? Ever thought about starting an Early Music group? In this class we'll discuss how to get started and how to improve the group you already have.

column3: How to do Chordal Music Analysis
column4: Ever wonder what people are talking about when the say "Oh it's another I IV V song" or "My goodness that's a strange cadence"? If so, this is class for you! In this class we'll go over basic chordal music analysis so you too will be able to hob-nob with musicians and impress your friends!
A kind of music theory 101 class. Students bring a pencil, I bring leopard and handouts with staff paper and musical examples.

This class is for anyone who learned to read music in high school band or orchestra, and is now playing early music. What are all those funny symbols and markings in the score that I never saw in marching band? we'll look at many scores and discuss how to understand them. If you have something that has puzzled you, bring it along and we'll look at it, too. Students are expected to be able to read music in modern notation, at least a little bit.

column3: Arranging Early Dance Music from Lute Tablature
column4: Want to learn how to write arrangements that won't make musicians cringe? This is the class for you! And you don't even have to read lute-tab to do it.

column3: Early Music in an Historical Context
column4: In this class we'll discuss text-painting, among other things.
What did Viking music sound like?

column3: Dance Music in the Vocal Realm
column4: This class is an exploration of dance music that crossed over into the vocal realm, either by evolving from songs or by evolving into songs. In some cases, the same composer was responsible for both the vocal and the dance compositions.
This class discusses troubadour songs/poems from a female point of view, especially the cantigas d'amigo (songs of a friend) from Iberia.
A shop class where you'll get to build period instruments out of PVC pipe.

column3: Master Class led by Master Christian
column4: Master Christian Leads the Third Annual St. Cecilia Master Class -- This is a class for performers to play a piece of 3 to 5 minutes in length that they have prepared ahead of time. They will then receive advice, suggestions and coaching from the instructor on their performance, and things they might do to improve it. The class is limited to 3 performing participants (or ensembles), with an unlimited number of auditors. Performers should expect to send a copy of the performing edition of their sheet music to the instructor a week ahead of time. Performers this year: Court & Country, The Pippins, and The Roaring Wastrels. [Difficulty Level 2.]

column3: History of Cheironomy (Gestures for Vocal Conducting)
column4: Cheironomy/Chironomy is the term for using hand signals to direct vocal music. This class explores the history of these gestures and their use in the past and present especially with regard to Gregorian chant and their relationship with modern conducting techniques. [Difficulty Level 1.]

A look at an early form of music and what might have become the saltarello. Bring an instrument and let's try a few. [Difficulty Levels 1 and 3 - The lecture portion will be at Level 1. Then the class moves to Level 3 for those who want to trying playing music.]

This class will examine the sounds of Norse culture through examining the archaeological and literary evidence, and then speculate about what the music tells us about the culture that produced it. [Difficulty Level 1 - The discussion of music theory will be only a small part of the talk and is intended to be accessible to beginners.]

column3: Interpretation of Renaissance Songs - Using Musical Clues to Shape Your Performance
column4: In this class we will look at how the meaning of the lyrics in Renaissance music can match with the musical shape of the song.  we'll go on an investigative journey through several examples to find the clues left by the composer which can help with phrasing, dynamics, and expression.  This is particularly useful when performing non-English pieces, and can help both your musicians and your audience get more out of the performance. [Difficulty Level 3.]
The very basics of modern music theory and ear training. [Difficulty Level 2-3.]

This class will explore Renaissance percussion instruments and basic playing technique.  Note this is primarily European percussion, not Middle Eastern, although there is certainly overlap.  Students should bring their own toys, some loaners will be available. [Approximately Difficulty Level 2 - Will move at a pace appropriate for Level 1 while being engaging for Level 3.]

Ground basses are standard sets of repeating chord progressions over which a melody can be improvised. In this class, we will discuss the use of ground basses during the Renaissance and learn how to play them. If the idea of improvising scares you, don't worry! You can just play or sing the basic chord progressions or do as much improvising as you feel comfortable with. [Difficulty Levels 2-4 - Students will be able to choose the complexity of their own improvisations.]

column3: The Quest for a New Musical Expression
column4: Full title - The Quest for a New Musical Expression: The Transformation of Musical Style from the Renaissance to the Early Baroque. Some composers are born at times when a given artistic style is well-established, speaking the preponderant musical language as naturally as they breathe. At other times, when previously dominant forms of expression are falling out of favor, aspiring young composers must struggle to shape their musical ideas into new and hitherto unexplored forms. This creates a diversity of "experimental" styles, until things settle down again, with the rise of a new dominant style. Here we will be looking at the transition that happened at the end of the 17th century, and the various approaches which eventually led to what we now call the Baroque. With plenty of musical examples, by composers ranging from Giovanni Gabrieli to Heinrich Schutz. [Difficulty Level 1.]

column3: The Development of Music Notation in Period
column4: From the murky beginnings of sketching tunes above lyrics to Renaissance diamond-shaped notes and white mensural notation, we will look at a series of notation systems and how they changed during our period. The (very opinionated) teacher will correlate styles of notation with the current musical styles and understandings of those days. No need to read music. [Difficulty Level 2-4.]

column3: Guido d’Arezzo and a Wonderful System for Ear Training and Sight-Singing from the 11th Century
column4: Learn the basics of the original solfege system which became our do, re, mi system. Learn how to use the Guidonian Hand for sight-singing. Learn the history and music theory behind it all. [Difficulty Level 3-4.]

Introduction to the troubadour and trouvere genre.  Fat handout includes many examples of different types of poems, a select bibliography, and websites. Class also touches on the difficulties associated with performing this genre and some possible solutions. [Difficulty Level 1.]

A how-to class on adding harmonies to melodies for a medieval sound.  Good for period tunes or new tunes. N.B.: Not Renaissance. [Difficulty Level 2-3 - This skill may be a new one for many musicians, but the concepts behind it are easy to learn!]

Come get a tour of the repertoire of Guillaume de Machaut, a prolific poet and composer of the 14th century.  Our goal in this class will be to review a range of different musical forms, and thus will be focused on sight-reading.  Some familiarity with an instrument is necessary.  While the class will be focused on instrumental parts, some songs will have lyrics and singers are welcome to attend. [Difficulty Level 3.]

An exploration of the development and canonization of melodies used in the Jewish prayer service, many of which are in use to this day!  Special attention is given to the medieval argument regarding whether music "incites people to sin," the difficulties in recording Jewish music in manuscript/print, and what differences exist between the Ashkenazim (France, Germany and surrounding areas) and the Sefardim (Spain, Italy and surrounding areas).

column3: How to Make Sounds on the Recorder
column4: Class 1 of the beginner track. Never played a recorder before? Used to play, but forgot what you learned? This class is for you. Don't have a recorder? we'll provide one for you.Topics covered include: how to hold the recorder; how to read and play a handful of pitches; how to start and stop making a sound; introduction to the five-line staff; simple rhythmic notation; how to take care of your recorder. [Difficulty Level 1.]

Class 2 of the beginner track. Learn to read and play simple rhythms on the recorder. Topics include: time signatures; more detailed discussion of rhythmic note values; more detailed discussion of rhythmic notation; rests; dotted notes; ties; even more pitches. [Difficulty Level 1.]

Class 3 of the beginner track. Learn to read and play specific pitches on the recorder. Topics include: more detail on the five-line staff and treble clef; expanded set of pitches; half-holing; several new melodies to play together. [Difficulty Level 1.]

column3: How to Play Easy Music with Others
column4: Class 4 of the beginner track. Learn to play simple part-music with other beginners. Topics include: rhythm reminders; pitch reminders; intonation; phrasing and articulation; simple two- and three-part music. [Difficulty Level 1.]

column3: How to Cope in an Ensemble
column4: Class 5 of the beginner track. Learn to play along with more advanced musicians by simplifying your part as you go. Topics include: following along; important pitches; tricks for simplifying your part; droning; practice tips. [Difficulty Level 2.]

This discussion is meant as a resource for anyone who sings in a choir, or wants to join one, or needs advice on how to lead one. Our panel of experienced directors will speak from their knowledge of singers and music, and will address questions and topics from the audience. Panelists: Master Christian d'Hiver, Mistress Gianetta Andreini da Vicenza, THL Jadwiga Krzyzanowska, and THL Teleri ferch Morgant ap Rhys (facilitator). [Difficulty Level 2, but people who aren't musicians (yet) might find some of the discussion interesting.]

Exploration of the Italian Ballata, both monophonic and polyphonic: Includes an exploration of the musical form as well as samples of a one-voice ballata and a three-voice ballata, followed by learning and singing or playing a two-voice ballata for a hands-on experience of the musical form (Ecco La Primavera by Francesco Landini). No sight-reading expertise is necessary; the two parts will be taught to the class. Instrumentalists and vocalists are both welcome.

column3: Guido d’Arezzo and a Wonderful System for Ear Training and Sight-Singing from the 11th Century
column4: Learn the basics of the original solfege system which became our do, re, mi system. Learn how to use the Guidonian Hand for sight-singing. Learn the history and music theory behind it all.

We'll start at 1200 A.D. in Western Europe (very traditional history), but then work our way backwards in a whirlwind tour of 3 continents and stretching back as far as we can -- we might even get to the Egyptians and Sumerians!  There is definitely some Chinese music from the Tang Dynasty extant -- let's see what we can find!

column3: Manuscripts, Motets and Modes: The Thirteenth Century in Western Music
column4: This class is a basic overview of major developments in Western European music from 1300-1400, with plenty of listening examples.  We'll look at music from the great manuscript collections, such as Carmina Burana and the Cantigas de Santa Maria, as well as the dawn of music with multiple parts, including the French motet, and. just briefly, trends in music notation and theory.

column3: Lads from the Low Countries; Music in the 15th Century
column4: In this class we'll discuss the contribution of the Franco-Flemish composers in the 15th century. Learn all about Melismas, Cantus Firmus, Imitation, and where all the Italians went.

column3: Court, Church, and Commoners: Music for Everyone in the 16th Century
column4: In this class we will discuss trends in Italian, English, French, and Spanish music of the 16th century, including a shift towards larger numbers of parts, an emphasis on homophonic texture, the use of imitative counterpoint, and the wider availability of printed music. We will listen to examples of sacred and secular genres including the mass and the madrigal, and instrumentations like the broken consort.
A sampling of medieval and Renaissance Christmas music. Music for sight reading will be included, so bring an instrument or your voice!
Learn effective techniques for warming up your voice in preparation for practice or performance.

Part 1: sources for finding modern editions of early music, primarily focused on freely-available Internet sources.

Part 2: Using the Internet to find images of original manuscripts and partbooks, including how to follow citations from modern editions to the original music.

column3: Learn a Part-Song Start to Finish
column4: A practical introduction to the process of learning a song, from start to finish. No experience necessary!

column3: How A Dying Swan Gave Life to Madrigals
column4: Ask 100 people to name a madrigal and Il Bianco e Dolce Cigno will probably come up in short order.  Explore this well-known, well-loved  madrigal by Jaques Arcadelt, including how this piece sent madrigals out of Italy and into the rest of Europe.  We'll listen to a few recordings, read a few translations, and discuss the different style choices therein. Come learn why this dying swan is one of the most enduring madrigals of all time.
We will write new period-style music to fit a period dance for which we have choreography but that is lacking music.

This workshop outlines the basic rules of sixteenth-century counterpoint, as put forth in the writings of Lanfranco, Zarlino, Zacconi, and Fux. Participants will learn these guidelines and use them to compose short polyphonic pieces.Prerequisites: Participants should be familiar with key music theory concepts (such as polyphony and homorhythm; major, minor, augmented, diminished, and perfect intervals; stepwise motion and skipwise motion; and consonance and dissonance). Participants should also be able to notate simple melodies, ideally without the aid of an instrument.

column3: A More Subtle Art: The Fourteenth Century in Western Music
column4: This class is a basic overview of major developments in Western European music from 1300-1400, with plenty of listening examples. We will cover ars nova, music of the Trecento, Geisslerlieder, and ars subtilior.

column3: Master Class led by Mistress Zsof
column4: Mistress Zsof Leads the Fourth Annual St. Cecilia Master Class -- This is a class for performers to play a piece of 3 to 5 minutes in length that they have prepared ahead of time. They will then receive advice, suggestions and coaching from the instructor on their performance, and things they might do to improve it. The class is limited to 3 performing participants (or ensembles), with an unlimited number of auditors. Performers should expect to send a copy of the performing edition of their sheet music to the instructor a week ahead of time.
Practice for the Miserere Mei Deus performance in the concert.
Guided sight reading. Primarily for instruments, but vocalists are also welcome.
Bring a madrigal or other easy part song and we will sing it!
Guided sight reading for vocalists and instrumentalists.
